data.title: Philly's 100+ Biggest Events & Fests for Fall 2024 & Beyond
data.meta_description: Looking for the biggest and best events and festivals in Philadelphia in 2024? Our detailed guide has you covered.
data.text:
Philly knows how to throw a party.

The City of Brotherly Love is a year-round destination for good food, good times and all-around revelry, including fun festivals, major concerts and brand-new exhibitions.

It’s last call for summer fun with popular outdoor attractions like Spruce Street Harbor Park and Independence Blue Cross RiverRink Summerfest, which wind down alongside the return of big annual events like the Philadelphia Polo Classic and Rittenhouse Square Fine Art Show and cultural fests like the PECO Multicultural Series and Dine Latino Restaurant Week.

Some of music’s biggest names take to Philly stages in the next few months, including Nicki Minaj, Sabrina Carpenter, Billie Eilish, Charli XCX and many more. Plus, look forward to stunning Broadway productions of shows like Hamilton, Les Misérables and The Book of Mormon.

Once the leaves get crunchy, you can fall back into both new and classic autumn happenings like Halloween Nights at Eastern State Penitentiary, the Puerto Rican Day Parade, the Head of the Schuylkill Regatta, the Philadelphia Film Festival and the Philadelphia Marathon.

Then Philly gets into the holiday spirit with the return of festive celebrations including the 6abc Dunkin’ Thanksgiving Day Parade, Christmas Village in Philadelphia, The Nutcracker at the Academy of Music, a special holiday concert from the one-and-only Mariah Carey and Philly’s 2nd annual Rocky Day celebration.

And looking ahead, 2025 sees the return of perennial Philly faves, including the PHS Philadelphia Flower Show and the Philadelphia Auto Show at the Pennsylvania Convention Center.

Can’t find your favorite event? Don’t worry. New events are added to this list regularly once they are officially announced.

One important note: Event dates and details can change at any time. Always check ahead with event organizers and/or on official event sites to confirm event dates and times.

Make it a vacation (or staycation) with the perfect hotel stay. Book the Visit Philly Overnight Package and get free hotel parking and choose-your-own-adventure perks, including two tickets to The Art of the Brick at The Franklin Institute (through Labor Day); the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the Rodin Museum; or the National Constitution Center and the Museum of the American Revolution. Or kick back a while with the Visit Philly 3-Day Stay hotel package, which includes buy-two-get-a-third-free hotel nights at participating hotels.

Here’s a look at the biggest events, festivals and exhibitions in Greater Philadelphia in 2024 — and beyond.

Note: This article is arranged in chronological order by event date.

— Photo by M. Stanley for Delaware River Waterfront Corporation

Through Monday, September 2, 2024

Time to don those sunnies. The seasonal Penn’s Landing extravaganza returns with an enormous arcade, more boardwalk games and carnival rides than ever, and urban beachside views of the Delaware River. The attraction has plenty of food and drink options, too, with crowd-pleasers like funnel cake at Skelly’s, cocktails at The Lodge Bar and crabfries from Chickie’s & Pete’s. New for 2024: a flashy 18-hole mini-golf course, new rides like a children’s roller coaster and whirling ride, and expanded food menus. Admission is free, everything else is pay-as-you-go, and note that the roller rink itself is closed for construction.

read more

Through Wednesday, September 25, 2024 (select dates)

Play ball! Philadelphia Phillies’ superstars Bryce Harper, Trea Turner and Zack Wheeler continue to tear up the field this summer and fall. Will it be another Red October? Let’s find out. See the online schedule for dates and times.

read more

Sponsored

Sponsored

— Photo by B. Mathias for Longwood Gardens

Through Sunday, October 27, 2024

This spring and summer, Longwood Gardens’ glorious fountains jet to life during the attraction’s annual Festival of Fountains. Performances include the daily Main Fountain Garden show with 1,719 jets soaring as high as 175 feet; the 110-year-old Open Air Theatre and its 750 jets in changing patterns spinning and dancing to music (daily except Tuesdays); and dazzling nighttime displays during spectacular Illuminated Fountain Performances, plus a cool behind-the-scenes tour (Thursdays through Saturdays).

read more

— Photo courtesy Ensemble Arts

Featuring the infectious music of ABBA, this feel-good, mother-daughter musical transports audiences to a gorgeous Greek island as a soon-to-be bride searches for her father on the eve of her wedding.

read more

Produced by the Philadelphia Folksong Society, this annual celebration of folk music features a lineup of contemporary and legendary folk artists. John Oates (of Hall & Oates) and genre-bending band Gangstagrass headline the 2024 fest alongside a fleet of additional performers. Also on the docket: camping, workshops and more.

read more

Back for its second year, The Philly Bookstore Crawl challenges book lovers to explore the region’s ever-growing collection of independently owned shops. There is no trail or route to follow but plenty of perks — surprise giveaways, discounted new reads, meet-and-greets with respected authors — are sprinkled among the 33 participating bookshops, including the Multiverse comic book store and the nation’s oldest LGBTQ+ and feminist bookstore, Philly Aids Thrift at Giovanni’s Room. Check the official website for additional details and the full list of bookstores.

read more

Talk about a glow-up. Everyone’s favorite miniature toy cars come to life as souped-up, mega-sized, glow-in-the-dark beasts. Hot Wheels-turned-real-life-monster-trucks Mega Wrex, Tiger Shark and Boneshaker battle it out on the floor of the Wells Fargo Center as laser lights, theatrical effects and dance parties take over the stadium. The show also features special appearances by the high-flying Freestyle Motorcross team and Megasaurus, a huge, transforming robot-dinosaur that literally eats cars for breakfast.

read more

— Photo courtesy Kennett Square Mushroom Festival

Did you know that the “Mushroom Capital of the World” is just outside of Philadelphia? To celebrate its unusual claim to fame, the charming town of Kennett Square hosts a two-day Mushroom Festival every September, full of fungi-themed food, live music, special exhibits, chef demonstrations and family-friendly activities.

read more

Spotlighting the bustling arts scene in Bucks County, the Doylestown Arts Festival is a two-day juried art, music and food showcase along the streets of Doylestown. This year — the festival’s 33rd anniversary — attendees can expect over 150 artists specializing in glass, pottery, wood, printmaking, live art demonstrations, music and a vast food court.

read more

— Photo courtesy Visit Delco, PA

The name says it all when Linvilla Orchards’ annual Pumpkinland opens for the season. The gourd gala features a slew of daytime ticketed activities like harvest hayrides around the farm, corn and (slightly harder) haybale mazes, apple blaster target shooting, pick-your-own crops, fishing in Orchard Lake, and pony and train rides. Things get spooky after dark with moonlight hayrides around the farm or to the nearby Witch’s House, ending at a campfire with cider and marshmallows. And don’t miss the annual Arts & Craft Festival season kickoff on September 14 and 15, 2024.

read more

— Photo courtesy Philadelphia Eagles

September 16 – December 29, 2024 (select dates)

Get pumped, Philly: The Philadelphia Eagles are back for the 2024-2025 season. Head to rollicking Lincoln Financial Field for the team’s post-Kelce-and-Graham era as Jalen Hurts, A.J. Brown and DeVonta Smith — debuting star newcomer Saquon Barkley — hit the gridiron for the Eagles’ home opener against NFC rival the Atlanta Falcons (Monday, September 16, 2024). Future home games this fall and early winter at The Linc include games against the Cleveland Browns (Sunday, October 13, 2024), the Jacksonville Jaguars (Sunday, November 3, 2024), the Washington Commanders (Thursday, November 14, 2024), the Carolina Panthers and the Pittsburgh Steelers (Sunday, December 15, 2024).

read more

Nearly 20 locations in Montgomery County — like Ardmore Music Hall, Elmwood Park Zoo and more — celebrate the living legacy of jazz, hosting performers all weekend during the third annual Montco Jazz Fest. Expect artist collaborations, tribute concerts, and showcases of styles from big band to jazz funk.

read more

Leading up to America’s Semiquincentennial in 2026, Visit Philadelphia and its partners — in collaboration with TED Democracy — celebrate the city’s legacy as the birthplace of modern democracy through high-profile events centered on concepts essential to preserving that freedom. 2024’s tentpole program is the TED Democracy Fireside Chat series, featuring talks from esteemed thought-leaders followed by moderated Q&A sessions with the audience (plus light bites and refreshments). The series’ second event comes in September, with a specific topic and live location to be announced soon.

read more

WXPN, the public radio station of the University of Pennsylvania, brings together musical legends and new performers along the Camden waterfront at this can’t-miss annual fest at Wiggins Waterfront Park. This year’s lineup includes The Walkmen, Rosanne Cash, Pete Yorn and many more.

read more

This ain’t your grandfather’s baseball team. The TikTok-famous baseballers take the field in South Philly for nine innings of trick pitches, choreographed dances and epic entrances.

read more

In 1824, the Marquis de Lafayette — a key French figure in the American Revolution — triumphantly returned to the U.S., visiting every state in the Union. For the 200th anniversary, the Bicentennial of Lafayette’s Farewell Tour retraces his steps, stopping in Philly for a week (plus a day in Bristol). Opening the stop is the free Here Comes General Lafayette! Parade, Music, & Events celebration, honoring the Major General with a parade across Independence Mall, history pop-ups, exhibitions, music and more, leading to the grand entrance of General Lafayette in a horse-drawn carriage.

read more

— Photo by B. Ballard for Concilio

¡Wepa! Thousands of spectators line the Benjamin Franklin Parkway for this annual parade and celebration of Latino culture. More than 1,500 marchers make their way down the Parkway each year, featuring traditional Latino music, dance performances, floats and more.

read more

Dates vary by concert

AHH! Philly’s music scene is scary-good this year. Here’s what to look forward to in October:

Jelly Roll at the Wells Fargo Center (October 2, 2024)

Billie Eilish at the Wells Fargo Center (October 5, 2024)

Lupe Fiasco at Union Transfer (October 5, 2024)

Sabrina Carpenter at the Wells Fargo Center (October 8, 2024)

Justin Timberlake at the Wells Fargo Center (October 11, 2024)

Maggie Rogers at the Wells Fargo Center (October 15, 2024)

Air at The Met Philadelphia (October 17, 2024)

The Black Keys at the Wells Fargo Center (October 21, 2024)

read more

It’s a bird … it’s a plane … it’s a GOAT? You might not have made it to Paris, but you can still experience the once-in-a-generation athleticism and talent that is Simone “The GOAT” Biles when the champion’s victory lap stops in Philadelphia. (Translation: GOAT stands for “greatest of all time.”) The freshly minted, four-time Olympic gold medalist flies into the Wells Fargo Center this October for her Gold Over America Tour, where some of the nation’s best gymnasts — including fellow Olympians Jordan Chiles, Jade Carey and Fred Richards — join her for this high-energy, high-flying, highly anticipated gymnastics show.

read more

Break out your favorite flannel for this fall celebration on the streets of Downingtown. The annual street festival features a day full of great food, handmade crafts and the fan-favorite Victory Beer Garden — serving up seasonal brews from Victory Brewing Company, the beloved brewery that was founded in the borough in 1996.

read more

Each year, Philadelphia and Indigenous communities from across the nation gather at Shackamaxon, also known as Penn Treaty Park, to mark five-plus centuries of Indigenous history and culture. This year’s Philadelphia’s Indigenous People’s Day celebration features speakers, performers, and vendors from as far away as Mexico and South America. The event is pay-what-you-wish, though suggested donations of $12 are encouraged.

read more

Cameras rolling … Each year, the Philadelphia Film Society’s team of curators travels to festivals around the globe — from Sundance to Cannes — in search of the most innovative new films. This year, they’ve brought back over 100 films from critically acclaimed filmmakers and newcomers to screen during the 11-day Philadelphia Film Festival, celebrating its 33rd year in 2024. Alongside screenings of full-length pieces and shorts representing a wide variety of different genres, the festival typically features panels and talkbacks with industry professionals as well as opportunities to connect with like-minded film enthusiasts. Stay tuned to the official website for the 2024 schedule of films and events.

read more

WWE superstars love Philly as much Philly loves (or loves to hate) them. This October, WWE World Heavyweight Champion Seth Rollins, reigning Intercontinental Champion Gunther, and who knows who else (it’s WWE — you never know what to expect!) return to the Wells Fargo Center for the first time since Wrestlemania 40. Dust off the old championship belt and head down to South Philly to join thousands of wailing fans in cheering on your favorite Raw superstars and catch all of the gravity-defying, in-ring action live.

read more

Among the largest festivals of its kind, the Philadelphia Asian American Film Festival celebrates and showcases the stories of Asians and Pacific Islanders in film, performance art, music and other creative expressions during its multi-day run.

Where: Locations TBA

read more

— Photo courtesy Philadelphia Museum of Art Craft Show

Museum-quality handmade jewelry, textiles and mixed media are on display and for sale during this juried show at the Pennsylvania Convention Center. Now in its 48th year, the show features 195 artists representing 13 different categories of art and design.

read more

Dates vary by concert

It’s the most wonderful time of the year — and the most wonderful city for music. Take off those earmuffs for these live concerts in Philly:

Mariah Carey’s Christmas Time at the Wells Fargo Center (December 3, 2024)

The No Name Pops: A Philly Holiday Spectacular at the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts (December 14, 2024)

The Philadelphia Orchestra Presents Disney’s The Muppet Christmas Carol in Concert at the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts (December 18-19, 2024)

read more

“God bless us, every one!” Ebenezer Scrooge — with a little help from three ghosts and Tiny Tim — finds the true meaning of Christmas in this kid-friendly musical adaptation of Charles Dickens’ holiday classic. Through the lens of the iconic miser, the age-old story explores the root of happiness and our potential for change.

read more

Hear that? Explosive and riveting, STOMP redefined musical performances 30 years ago with its innovative use of everything but traditional percussion instruments — from garbage cans and hubcaps to brooms and poles. Tucked right between Christmas and New Year’s, the rhythmic show comes to Philly’s Miller Theater with a production as exhilarating as ever.

read more

DJ Mickey hops on the 1s and 2s for this fun and energetic new performance from Disney On Ice. Witness virtuoso figure skating, thrilling stunts and high-flying acrobatics, with colorful remixes of your favorite Disney tunes and character cameos from Wish, Frozen 2, The Lion King, The Little Mermaid, Moana and more.

read more

Come for Philadelphia. Stay (Over) for Philly.

The only way to fully experience Philly? Stay over.

Book the Visit Philly Overnight Package and get free hotel parking and choose-your-own-adventure perks, including tickets to the Philadelphia Museum of Art, The Franklin Institute, or the National Constitution Center and the Museum of the American Revolution.

Or maybe you’d prefer to buy two Philly hotel nights and get a third night for free? Then book the new Visit Philly 3-Day Stay package.

Which will you choose?

book now
